elements.content: A practical porous crystalline matrix for molecular structure determination of a wide range of liquid chemicals has been set up. We herein report proof-of-concept research on the temperature-dependent single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) guest exchange of the P- and M-helix-enantiomeric multilayered ensemble with flexible open-channels of the shortest diameter, 4.4 × 4.4 Å2. This landmark ensemble is, to the best of our knowledge, the most efficient, practical, tolerant, and reproducible porous matrix for single crystal structure determination of general liquid compounds via easy SCSC guest exchange without any desolvation process. The innovative channel behaves in a guest-dependent flexible response manner and enables scientists to solve structures of a wide range of liquid chemicals. This paper reports the molecular structures of 41 liquid chemicals including chiral and natural compounds via guest exchange at >75% success rate.
elements.clean_text: A practical porous crystalline matrix for molecular structure determination of a wide range of liquid chemicals has been set up. We herein report proof-of-concept research on the temperature-dependent single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) guest exchange of the P- and M-helix-enantiomeric multilayered ensemble with flexible open-channels of the shortest diameter, 4.4 × 4.4 Å2. This landmark ensemble is, to the best of our knowledge, the most efficient, practical, tolerant, and reproducible porous matrix for single crystal structure determination of general liquid compounds via easy SCSC guest exchange without any desolvation process. The innovative channel behaves in a guest-dependent flexible response manner and enables scientists to solve structures of a wide range of liquid chemicals. This paper reports the molecular structures of 41 liquid chemicals including chiral and natural compounds via guest exchange at  >75% success rate.

elements.content:
A flexible porous matrix enables scientists to solve molecular structures of a wide range of liquid chemicals via SCSC guest exchange.

Introduction

The burgeoning need for practical task-specific applications of novel porous coordination polymer crystals has motivated many chemists over the course of the past two decades. In particular, solvation/desolvation in crystallization via self-assembled constructions of central metal ions with appropriate spacer ligands is a significant process enabling understanding of desirable confined spaces for adsorption/desorption, gas storage, molecular recognition, anion exchange, magnetism-tuning, catalysis, molecular reactor, and porous templates for molecular structure determination of liquid compounds. M. Fujita’s group reported the observation of guest molecular structures through the guest uptake into porous metal complexes, as the concept of the crystalline sponge method. M. Antipin’s group studied the low-temperature crystallization method of the liquid in a thin capillary. Extensive factors such as coordination geometry of metal ions, donating nature of ligands, metal/ligand ratio, solvents, and unexpected weak interactions are related symbiotically with each other, obtaining desirable porous crystals, and, thus, systematic research on a comprehensive list of factors is needed to construct practical porous coordination frameworks. Among the various coordination frameworks, some 2D topological materials have been employed as reasonable prototypes for site-selective templates, storage, and small-molecular containers.
elements.clean_text:
A flexible porous matrix enables scientists to solve molecular structures of a wide range of liquid chemicals via SCSC guest exchange.

Introduction

The burgeoning need for practical task-specific applications of novel porous coordination polymer crystals has motivated many chemists over the course of the past two decades. In particular, solvation/desolvation in crystallization via self-assembled constructions of central metal ions with appropriate spacer ligands is a significant process enabling understanding of desirable confined spaces for adsorption/desorption, gas storage, molecular recognition, anion exchange, magnetism-tuning, catalysis, molecular reactor, and porous templates for molecular structure determination of liquid compounds. M. Fujita's group reported the observation of guest molecular structures through the guest uptake into porous metal complexes, as the concept of the crystalline sponge method. M. Antipin's group studied the low-temperature crystallization method of the liquid in a thin capillary. Extensive factors such as coordination geometry of metal ions, donating nature of ligands, metal/ligand ratio, solvents, and unexpected weak interactions are related symbiotically with each other, obtaining desirable porous crystals, and, thus, systematic research on a comprehensive list of factors is needed to construct practical porous coordination frameworks. Among the various coordination frameworks, some 2D topological materials have been employed as reasonable prototypes for site-selective templates, storage, and small-molecular containers.

elements.content: Recent results on substantial 2D coordination polymer crystals demonstrate that solvation phenomenon, structural modulation, and dynamic transformation provide further insights into rational single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) host–guest control. Specifically, rational guest exchange within the confined spaces of 2D topological crystals possibly can be induced by various types of weak intermolecular interactions between frameworks and guest compounds such as hydrogen bonding, ion–dipole and dipole–dipole attractions, van der Waals forces, and interactions via decrease of Gibbs free energy relative to the solvent’s and 2D skeleton’s free energy. A noteworthy conceptual feature of 2D framework materials is guest-induced interlayer sliding and stretching. The bulkiness of guest molecules can be a significant factor in both the host–guest exchange process and interlayer sliding because it can control the orientation of guest molecules via the weak interaction between guest molecules and host skeletons. The polarity, protic properties, coordinating ability, and bulkiness of common guest molecules can be critical factors to both crystallization and guest exchange within porous crystalline hosts. Furthermore, such host–guest exchange chemistry can be strongly dependent on temperature, which indeed is a momentous factor in the solvation/desolvation process of porous crystals.
elements.clean_text: Recent results on substantial 2D coordination polymer crystals demonstrate that solvation phenomenon, structural modulation, and dynamic transformation provide further insights into rational single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) host-guest control. Specifically, rational guest exchange within the confined spaces of 2D topological crystals possibly can be induced by various types of weak intermolecular interactions between frameworks and guest compounds such as hydrogen bonding, ion-dipole and dipole-dipole attractions, van der Waals forces, and interactions via decrease of Gibbs free energy relative to the solvent's and 2D skeleton's free energy. A noteworthy conceptual feature of 2D framework materials is guest-induced interlayer sliding and stretching. The bulkiness of guest molecules can be a significant factor in both the host-guest exchange process and interlayer sliding because it can control the orientation of guest molecules via the weak interaction between guest molecules and host skeletons. The polarity, protic properties, coordinating ability, and bulkiness of common guest molecules can be critical factors to both crystallization and guest exchange within porous crystalline hosts. Furthermore, such host-guest exchange chemistry can be strongly dependent on temperature, which indeed is a momentous factor in the solvation/desolvation process of porous crystals.

elements.content: In this context, advanced practical research on the most efficient porous matrices for structure determination of general liquid chemicals via easy SCSC guest exchanges without any desolvation herein is reported, notwithstanding the several studies on simple SCSC exchange that have been presented in the literature. This article aims to provide the proof-of-concept experiments of 2D ensemble’s channels on the most efficient, practical, reproducible, tolerant, and flexible porous matrix for single crystal X-ray structure determination of general liquid chemicals containing a wide range of bulkiness and functional groups. The novel helix-enantiomeric multilayered ensemble was efficiently obtained as a unique porous matrix from self-assembly of AgX (X– = CF3SO3 – and PF6 –) with C 3-symmetric 1,3,5-tris­(isonicotinoyl-oxymethyl)­benzene (L).
elements.clean_text: In this context, advanced practical research on the most efficient porous matrices for structure determination of general liquid chemicals via easy SCSC guest exchanges without any desolvation herein is reported, notwithstanding the several studies on simple SCSC exchange that have been presented in the literature. This article aims to provide the proof-of-concept experiments of 2D ensemble's channels on the most efficient, practical, reproducible, tolerant, and flexible porous matrix for single crystal X-ray structure determination of general liquid chemicals containing a wide range of bulkiness and functional groups. The novel helix-enantiomeric multilayered ensemble was efficiently obtained as a unique porous matrix from self-assembly of AgX (X- = CF3SO3 - and PF6 -) with C 3-symmetric 1,3,5-tris(isonicotinoyl-oxymethyl)benzene (L).

elements.content: All chemicals including silver­(I) hexafluorophosphate (AgPF6) and silver­(I) trifluoromethanesulfonate (triflate: AgCF3SO3) were purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification. 1,3,5-Tris­(isonicotinoyloxy-methyl)­benzene (L) was synthesized according to the procedure available in the literature. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian Mercury Plus 300 operating at 300 and 75 MHz, respectively. Infrared spectra were obtained on a Nicolet 380 FT-IR spectrophotometer with samples prepared as KBr pellets. Elemental microanalyses (C, H, N) were performed on solid samples by the Pusan center, KBSI, using a Vario-EL III. Thermal analyses were carried out under a dinitrogen atmosphere at a scan rate of 10 °C/min using a Labsys TGA-DSC 1600. Powder X-ray diffraction data were recorded on a D8 discover and GADDS system (Bruker AXS) at 3 kW for Cu Kα.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All chemicals including silver(I) hexafluorophosphate (AgPF6) and silver(I) trifluoromethanesulfonate (triflate: AgCF3SO3) were purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification. 1,3,5-Tris(isonicotinoyloxy-methyl)benzene (L) was synthesized according to the procedure available in the literature. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian Mercury Plus 300 operating at 300 and 75 MHz, respectively. Infrared spectra were obtained on a Nicolet 380 FT-IR spectrophotometer with samples prepared as KBr pellets. Elemental microanalyses (C, H, N) were performed on solid samples by the Pusan center, KBSI, using a Vario-EL III. Thermal analyses were carried out under a dinitrogen atmosphere at a scan rate of 10 °C/min using a Labsys TGA-DSC 1600. Powder X-ray diffraction data were recorded on a D8 discover and GADDS system (Bruker AXS) at 3 kW for Cu Kα.

elements.content: A methanol solution (2 mL) of AgCF3SO3 (2.57 mg, 0.01 mmol) was slowly diffused into a tetrahydrofuran solution (2 mL) of L (4.83 mg, 0.01 mmol). Colorless [Ag2(CF3SO3)2L2]·2C4H8O·2/3CH3OH·1/3H2O crystals were formed at the interface and were obtained after 5 days in a 61.2% yield. mp 230 °C (dec). Anal. Calcd for C194H184Ag6F18N18O63S6: C, 47.1; H, 3.79; N, 5.07%. Found: C, 46.90; H, 3.71; N, 5.12%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 1726 (s), 1411 (s), 1328 (s), 1276 (s, CF3SO3 –), 1162 (s, CF3SO3 –), 1122 (s), 1047 (m), 1031 (s, CF3SO3 –), 755 (s), 701 (s), 647 (m).
elements.clean_text:
2(THF)⋅2/3(MeOH)⋅1/3(H2O)@1

A methanol solution (2 mL) of AgCF3SO3 (2.57 mg, 0.01 mmol) was slowly diffused into a tetrahydrofuran solution (2 mL) of L (4.83 mg, 0.01 mmol). Colorless [Ag2(CF3SO3)2L2]⋅2C4H8O⋅2/3CH3OH⋅1/3H2O crystals were formed at the interface and were obtained after 5 days in a 61.2% yield. mp 230 °C (dec). Anal. Calcd for C194H184Ag6F18N18O63S6: C, 47.1; H, 3.79; N, 5.07%. Found: C, 46.90; H, 3.71; N, 5.12%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 1726 (s), 1411 (s), 1328 (s), 1276 (s, CF3SO3 -), 1162 (s, CF3SO3 -), 1122 (s), 1047 (m), 1031 (s, CF3SO3 -), 755 (s), 701 (s), 647 (m).

elements.content: A tetrahydrofuran solution (2 mL) of L (4.83 mg, 0.01 mmol) was slowly diffused into an aqueous solution (2 mL) of AgPF6 (2.53 mg, 0.01 mmol). Colorless of [Ag2L2(C4H8O)2]­(PF6)2·C4H8O crystals were formed at the interface and were obtained after 5 days in a 66% yield. mp 226 °C (dec). Anal. Calcd for C66H66N6O15P2Ag2F12: C, 46.94; H, 3.94; N, 4.98%. Found: C, 47.10; H, 4.01; N, 4.82%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 1724 (s), 1268 (s), 1124 (m), 835 (s, PF6 –), 754 (s), 705 (s), 563 (m).
elements.clean_text:
THF@2

A tetrahydrofuran solution (2 mL) of L (4.83 mg, 0.01 mmol) was slowly diffused into an aqueous solution (2 mL) of AgPF6 (2.53 mg, 0.01 mmol). Colorless of [Ag2L2(C4H8O)2](PF6)2⋅C4H8O crystals were formed at the interface and were obtained after 5 days in a 66% yield. mp 226 °C (dec). Anal. Calcd for C66H66N6O15P2Ag2F12: C, 46.94; H, 3.94; N, 4.98%. Found: C, 47.10; H, 4.01; N, 4.82%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 1724 (s), 1268 (s), 1124 (m), 835 (s, PF6 -), 754 (s), 705 (s), 563 (m).

elements.content: Single crystals of [Ag6(CF3SO3)6L6]·6C4H8O·2CH3OH·H2O were left in dioxane media at 10, 30, 50, and 70 °C for 4 days, resulting in the transformation of single crystals of [Ag2(CF3SO3)2L2]·3C4H8O2. mp 230 °C (dec). Anal. Calcd for C34H33N3O12SF3Ag: C, 46.80; H, 3.81; N, 4.82%. Found: C, 46.30; H, 3.68; N, 3.77%. One drop of the liquid sample (20 μL) was dropped on a single crystal, and left for 12 h. Such treatment is sufficient to take the single crystal X-ray diffraction data.
elements.clean_text:
3(Dioxane)@1 via SCSC Solvate Exchange

Single crystals of [Ag6(CF3SO3)6L6]⋅6C4H8O⋅2CH3OH⋅H2O were left in dioxane media at 10, 30, 50, and 70 °C for 4 days, resulting in the transformation of single crystals of [Ag2(CF3SO3)2L2]⋅3C4H8O2. mp 230 °C (dec). Anal. Calcd for C34H33N3O12SF3Ag: C, 46.80; H, 3.81; N, 4.82%. Found: C, 46.30; H, 3.68; N, 3.77%. One drop of the liquid sample (20 μL) was dropped on a single crystal, and left for 12 h. Such treatment is sufficient to take the single crystal X-ray diffraction data.

elements.content:
The other (guest)@1 species are obtained by the same method using various liquid chemicals instead of dioxane.

Crystal Structure Determination

All X-ray data were collected on a Bruker SMART automatic diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and a CCD detector at ambient temperature. Thirty-six frames of two-dimensional diffraction images were collected and processed to obtain the cell parameters and orientation matrix. The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. The absorption effects were corrected using the multiscan method (SADABS). The structures were solved using the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques (SHELXL 2014/07). The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and the hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined only for the isotropic thermal factors. The crystal parameters and procedural information corresponding to the data collection and structure refinement are listed in Table S1. The X-ray crystallographic data have been deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC), under deposition numbers CCDC 1556245–1556286. These data can be obtained free of charge (http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif). The spectroscopic data along with the crystal structures can be found in the Supporting Information.

The other (guest)@1 species are obtained by the same method using various liquid chemicals instead of dioxane.

Crystal Structure Determination

All X-ray data were collected on a Bruker SMART automatic diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and a CCD detector at ambient temperature. Thirty-six frames of two-dimensional diffraction images were collected and processed to obtain the cell parameters and orientation matrix. The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. The absorption effects were corrected using the multiscan method (SADABS). The structures were solved using the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques (SHELXL 2014/07). The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and the hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined only for the isotropic thermal factors. The crystal parameters and procedural information corresponding to the data collection and structure refinement are listed in Table S1. The X-ray crystallographic data have been deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC), under deposition numbers CCDC 1556245-1556286. These data can be obtained free of charge (http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif). The spectroscopic data along with the crystal structures can be found in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: The overall procedure for the construction and SCSC guest exchange of the helix-enantiomeric multilayered 2D coordination ensemble channels is outlined in . Self-assembly of AgX (X– = CF3SO3 – and PF6 –) with C 3-symmetric tridentate N-donor (L) produces single crystals consisting of 2D networks, [Ag2(CF3SO3)2L2]·2C4H8O·2/3CH3OH·1/3H2O (2­(THF)·2/3­(MeOH)·1/3­(H2O)@1) and [Ag2L2(C4H8O)2]­(PF6)2·C4H8O (THF@2), respectively, in high yields. Anions play an important role in the construction of the 2D networks: hexafluorophosphate (PF6 –) anion acts as a counteranion whereas triflate (CF3SO3 –) anion acts as an anionic coordinating moiety. Furthermore, the noncoordinating hexafluorophosphate anion induces a multilayered ensemble in the staggered mode, whereas the coordinating triflate anion affords a multilayered ensemble in an approximately eclipsed fashion with open channels. The C 3-symmetric tridentate ligand moiety induces the enantiomeric multilayers with P- or M-helices. The self-assemblies were initially conducted in the 1:1 mol ratio of Ag­(I) ion to L, but the formations of 1 and 2 species were not significantly affected by the reactant mole ratios or concentration, indicating that the products were thermodynamically stable. Both crystalline products are stable and insoluble in water and common organic solvents but are dissociated in dimethyl sulfoxide.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Construction of 2D Ensemble Channel

The overall procedure for the construction and SCSC guest exchange of the helix-enantiomeric multilayered 2D coordination ensemble channels is outlined in . Self-assembly of AgX (X- = CF3SO3 - and PF6 -) with C 3-symmetric tridentate N-donor (L) produces single crystals consisting of 2D networks, [Ag2(CF3SO3)2L2]⋅2C4H8O⋅2/3CH3OH⋅1/3H2O (2(THF)⋅2/3(MeOH)⋅1/3(H2O)@1) and [Ag2L2(C4H8O)2](PF6)2⋅C4H8O (THF@2), respectively, in high yields. Anions play an important role in the construction of the 2D networks: hexafluorophosphate (PF6 -) anion acts as a counteranion whereas triflate (CF3SO3 -) anion acts as an anionic coordinating moiety. Furthermore, the noncoordinating hexafluorophosphate anion induces a multilayered ensemble in the staggered mode, whereas the coordinating triflate anion affords a multilayered ensemble in an approximately eclipsed fashion with open channels. The C 3-symmetric tridentate ligand moiety induces the enantiomeric multilayers with P- or M-helices. The self-assemblies were initially conducted in the 1:1 mol ratio of Ag(I) ion to L, but the formations of 1 and 2 species were not significantly affected by the reactant mole ratios or concentration, indicating that the products were thermodynamically stable. Both crystalline products are stable and insoluble in water and common organic solvents but are dissociated in dimethyl sulfoxide.

elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Diagram for the Construction, Single-Crystal-to-Single-Crystal (SCSC) Guest Exchange Procedure, and with Applications of 2D Ensemble Channels

elements.content: The crystal structure of 2­(THF)·2/3­(MeOH)·1/3­(H2O)@1 is shown in and , and their relevant crystallographic data are listed in Tables S1. All of the silver­(I) ions have a distorted tetrahedral arrangement with three N-donors from three ligands and one O-donor from triflate anion. The Ag­(I) centers and Ls can be defined as a 3-connected node, which results in a 2D coordination network constituted of a 54-membered metallacyclic unit with a uninodal hcb net topology with the Schläfli point symbol {63}. As indicated in Table S1, the 2D networks were packed in a multilayered mode as a P b M c P c i M b i P a i M ··· (a, b, c = layer; i = inversion center; P = P-helix, M = M-helix) via interlayer π–π interactions, resulting in the formation of 2D ensembles with open channels of the shortest diameter, 4.4 × 4.4 Å2 (0 0 1 direction). The channel dimension is dependent on the exchanged guest molecules (), which reflects the fact that the channels are somewhat flexible for the accommodation of various liquid chemicals, as will be explained in detail. The skeletal structure of THF@2 (Figure S1) is basically similar to that of the 1 series, with the exception that a tetrahydrofuran solvate molecule is coordinated to the Ag­(I) center instead of hexafluorophosphate counteranion, as is consistent with the metallophilicity of anions. That is, hexafluorophosphate (PF6) anion acts as a counteranion rather than an anionic ligand (the shortest distance of Ag···FPF5 = 4.3542(1) Å). The skeletal 2D networks were found to be packed in the staggered multilayered mode a P a 2 P a m M a 2,m M ··· (2 = C 2 operation; m = mirror operation). Thus, the skeleton does not have open channels; instead, both the coordinated tetrahydrofuran molecules and the simple solvate tetrahydrofuran molecules were safely nestled within the closed pores.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures and Channel Properties

The crystal structure of 2(THF)⋅2/3(MeOH)⋅1/3(H2O)@1 is shown in  and , and their relevant crystallographic data are listed in Tables S1. All of the silver(I) ions have a distorted tetrahedral arrangement with three N-donors from three ligands and one O-donor from triflate anion. The Ag(I) centers and Ls can be defined as a 3-connected node, which results in a 2D coordination network constituted of a 54-membered metallacyclic unit with a uninodal hcb net topology with the Schläfli point symbol {63}. As indicated in Table S1, the 2D networks were packed in a multilayered mode as a  P  b  M  c  P  c  i   M  b  i   P  a  i   M ⋅⋅⋅ (a, b, c = layer; i = inversion center; P = P-helix, M = M-helix) via interlayer π-π interactions, resulting in the formation of 2D ensembles with open channels of the shortest diameter, 4.4 × 4.4 Å2 (0 0 1 direction). The channel dimension is dependent on the exchanged guest molecules (), which reflects the fact that the channels are somewhat flexible for the accommodation of various liquid chemicals, as will be explained in detail. The skeletal structure of THF@2 (Figure S1) is basically similar to that of the 1 series, with the exception that a tetrahydrofuran solvate molecule is coordinated to the Ag(I) center instead of hexafluorophosphate counteranion, as is consistent with the metallophilicity of anions. That is, hexafluorophosphate (PF6) anion acts as a counteranion rather than an anionic ligand (the shortest distance of Ag⋅⋅⋅FPF5 = 4.3542(1) Å). The skeletal 2D networks were found to be packed in the staggered multilayered mode a  P  a 2  P  a  m   M  a 2,m   M ⋅⋅⋅ (2 = C 2 operation; m = mirror operation). Thus, the skeleton does not have open channels; instead, both the coordinated tetrahydrofuran molecules and the simple solvate tetrahydrofuran molecules were safely nestled within the closed pores.

elements.content: Detailed crystal structure for 2­(THF)·2/3­(MeOH)·1/3­(H2O)@1 showing geometry around Ag­(I) (a), side and top views of multilayered open-channel status (b), and ligand helicity (c).
elements.clean_text: 1  Detailed crystal structure for 2(THF)⋅2/3(MeOH)⋅1/3(H2O)@1 showing geometry around Ag(I) (a), side and top views of multilayered open-channel status (b), and ligand helicity (c).

elements.content: Crystal structure of 2­(THF)·2/3­(MeOH)·1/3­(H2O)@1 in the (1 0 1̅) direction, showing the entrance shape of channels constructed via interlayer π–π interactions of 2D ensembles. The inset shows the hcb (63) topological skeleton of the monolayered 2D. The green color designates the inner-area of the channels. n-Dodecane@1.
elements.clean_text: 2  Crystal structure of 2(THF)⋅2/3(MeOH)⋅1/3(H2O)@1 in the (1 0 1̅) direction, showing the entrance shape of channels constructed via interlayer π-π interactions of 2D ensembles. The inset shows the hcb (63) topological skeleton of the monolayered 2D. The green color designates the inner-area of the channels. n-Dodecane@1.

elements.content: Schematic image showing interlayer stretching and sliding directions of 2D layers (a). Channel shapes based on flexible response manner depending on bulkiness and shape of guest molecules, 2­(THF)·2/3­(MeOH)·1/3­(H2O)@1 (b), 8/3­(iso-PrOH)@1 (c), trans-Decahydronaphthalene@1 (d), 3/2­(Styrene)@1 (e), and n-Dodecane@1 (f).
elements.clean_text: 3  Schematic image showing interlayer stretching and sliding directions of 2D layers (a). Channel shapes based on flexible response manner depending on bulkiness and shape of guest molecules, 2(THF)⋅2/3(MeOH)⋅1/3(H2O)@1 (b), 8/3(iso-PrOH)@1 (c), trans-Decahydronaphthalene@1 (d), 3/2(Styrene)@1 (e), and n-Dodecane@1 (f).

elements.content: The volumes of solvate molecules in 2­(THF)·2/3­(MeOH)·1/3­(H2O)@1 and THF@2 were 21.1% (1076.2 Å3/5099.9 Å3) and 23.1% (1598.2 Å3/ 6910.4 Å3 including coordinated tetrahydrofuran), respectively, as determined on the basis of the PLATON/SOLV calculation. In order to confirm the evaporation temperature of the solvate molecules, the overlays of their thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) were measured. The TGA and DSC curves of 2­(THF)·2/3­(MeOH)·1/3­(H2O)@1 and THF@2 showed a drastic decomposition at 230 and 226 °C, respectively, corresponding to the collapse of each skeleton (Figure S2). The skeletal structures’ temperature collapse could be attributable to the stable multilayered ensembles. For 2­(THF)·2/3­(MeOH)·1/3­(H2O)@1, all solvate molecules evaporate in the range of 25–152 °C (Found: 10.4 wt %, Calcd: 9.1 wt %). For THF@2, the simple solvate tetrahydrofuran molecules evaporate in the 50–80 °C range (Found: 4.0 wt %, Calcd: 4.3 wt %), and the coordinated tetrahydrofuran molecules in the range of 170–190 °C (Found: 8.3 wt %, Calcd: 8.5 wt %). These evaporation temperatures of the solvate molecules are consistent with the open channels for the 1 series and the closed pores for THF@2. All solvate molecules of 2­(THF)·2/3­(MeOH)·1/3­(H2O)@1 and THF@2 were also confirmed by 1H NMR spectra in Me2SO-d 6 (Figure S3), even though the products were dissociated in the solution.
elements.clean_text: The volumes of solvate molecules in 2(THF)⋅2/3(MeOH)⋅1/3(H2O)@1 and THF@2 were 21.1% (1076.2 Å3/5099.9 Å3) and 23.1% (1598.2 Å3/ 6910.4 Å3 including coordinated tetrahydrofuran), respectively, as determined on the basis of the PLATON/SOLV calculation. In order to confirm the evaporation temperature of the solvate molecules, the overlays of their thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) were measured. The TGA and DSC curves of 2(THF)⋅2/3(MeOH)⋅1/3(H2O)@1 and THF@2 showed a drastic decomposition at 230 and 226 °C, respectively, corresponding to the collapse of each skeleton (Figure S2). The skeletal structures' temperature collapse could be attributable to the stable multilayered ensembles. For 2(THF)⋅2/3(MeOH)⋅1/3(H2O)@1, all solvate molecules evaporate in the range of 25-152 °C (Found: 10.4 wt %, Calcd: 9.1 wt %). For THF@2, the simple solvate tetrahydrofuran molecules evaporate in the 50-80 °C range (Found: 4.0 wt %, Calcd: 4.3 wt %), and the coordinated tetrahydrofuran molecules in the range of 170-190 °C (Found: 8.3 wt %, Calcd: 8.5 wt %). These evaporation temperatures of the solvate molecules are consistent with the open channels for the 1 series and the closed pores for THF@2. All solvate molecules of 2(THF)⋅2/3(MeOH)⋅1/3(H2O)@1 and THF@2 were also confirmed by 1H NMR spectra in Me2SO-d 6 (Figure S3), even though the products were dissociated in the solution.

elements.content: In this context, 2­(THF)·2/3­(MeOH)·1/3­(H2O)@1 crystals with open channels were employed as host materials for SCSC guest exchange. While they were simply immersed in the respective liquid guest systems, the solvate molecules were successfully exchanged by general liquid chemicals in the SCSC state. The amount of a liquid guest added to the one single crystal was about 20 μL. The SCSC guest exchanges of 2­(THF)·2/3­(MeOH)·1/3­(H2O)@1 into 3­(Dioxane)@1 in dioxane media and into 3­(Benzene)@1 in benzene media were monitored by 1H NMR spectra (a and S4a). In order to investigate the temperature effects on SCSC guest exchange, exchanges of 2­(THF)·2/3­(MeOH)·1/3­(H2O)@1 in both dioxane and benzene at 10, 30, 50, and 70 °C (b and S4b) were carried out. The SCSC exchange rate was exponentially proportional to the temperature. The exchange trials were completed within 1 day at 70 °C, 3 days at 50 °C, and 4 days at 30 °C, and the guest exchange was accomplished in 60% after 4 days at 10 °C. The dashed line in b indicates a guest exchange rate sufficient to afford single crystals suitable for X-ray single crystallographic data for the molecular structure of exchanged guest molecules. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first observation of the significant temperature effects of a systematic SCSC guest exchange. The complete exchanged species was confirmed by both chemical analyses and the 1H NMR spectra in Me2SO-d 6. The PXRD spectra of the original 2­(THF)·2/3­(MeOH)·1/3­(H2O)@1 crystals and the exchanged 3­(Dioxane)@1 and 3­(Benzene)@1 crystals showed similar patterns (Figure S5a), indicating that their crystallinity was preserved before and after the SCSC solvate exchange. Furthermore, their IR spectra remained virtually unchanged (Figure S5b), suggesting that after the guest exchange the molecular ensemble is not significantly changed. Thus, the most important feature is that the SCSC guest exchange is efficiently accomplished in a wide range of liquid chemicals such as short and long, bulky and nonbulky, racemic and chiral, alkene and alkyne, aromatic and aliphatic compounds, irrespective of the functional groups listed in a. Ortep drawings for all of the guest molecules nestled within the channel were shown in Figure S6.
elements.clean_text:
SCSC Guest Exchange and Molecular Structures of Liquid Guest Molecules

In this context, 2(THF)⋅2/3(MeOH)⋅1/3(H2O)@1 crystals with open channels were employed as host materials for SCSC guest exchange. While they were simply immersed in the respective liquid guest systems, the solvate molecules were successfully exchanged by general liquid chemicals in the SCSC state. The amount of a liquid guest added to the one single crystal was about 20 μL. The SCSC guest exchanges of 2(THF)⋅2/3(MeOH)⋅1/3(H2O)@1 into 3(Dioxane)@1 in dioxane media and into 3(Benzene)@1 in benzene media were monitored by 1H NMR spectra (a and S4a). In order to investigate the temperature effects on SCSC guest exchange, exchanges of 2(THF)⋅2/3(MeOH)⋅1/3(H2O)@1 in both dioxane and benzene at 10, 30, 50, and 70 °C (b and S4b) were carried out. The SCSC exchange rate was exponentially proportional to the temperature. The exchange trials were completed within 1 day at 70 °C, 3 days at 50 °C, and 4 days at 30 °C, and the guest exchange was accomplished in 60% after 4 days at 10 °C. The dashed line in b indicates a guest exchange rate sufficient to afford single crystals suitable for X-ray single crystallographic data for the molecular structure of exchanged guest molecules. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first observation of the significant temperature effects of a systematic SCSC guest exchange. The complete exchanged species was confirmed by both chemical analyses and the 1H NMR spectra in Me2SO-d 6. The PXRD spectra of the original 2(THF)⋅2/3(MeOH)⋅1/3(H2O)@1 crystals and the exchanged 3(Dioxane)@1 and 3(Benzene)@1 crystals showed similar patterns (Figure S5a), indicating that their crystallinity was preserved before and after the SCSC solvate exchange. Furthermore, their IR spectra remained virtually unchanged (Figure S5b), suggesting that after the guest exchange the molecular ensemble is not significantly changed. Thus, the most important feature is that the SCSC guest exchange is efficiently accomplished in a wide range of liquid chemicals such as short and long, bulky and nonbulky, racemic and chiral, alkene and alkyne, aromatic and aliphatic compounds, irrespective of the functional groups listed in a. Ortep drawings for all of the guest molecules nestled within the channel were shown in Figure S6.

elements.content: Time-dependent 1H NMR monitoring of SCSC guest exchange 2­(THF)·2/3­(MeOH)·1/3­(H2O)@1 to 3­(Dioxane)@1 at 50 °C (dagger, Me2SO-d 6; red, dioxane) (a), the SCSC guest exchange yield (b) depending on the temperature, 70 °C (green), 50 °C (blue), 30 °C (red), and 10 °C (black), and inset show crystallinity before and after SCSC guest exchange.
elements.clean_text: 4  Time-dependent 1H NMR monitoring of SCSC guest exchange 2(THF)⋅2/3(MeOH)⋅1/3(H2O)@1 to 3(Dioxane)@1 at 50 °C (dagger, Me2SO-d 6; red, dioxane) (a), the SCSC guest exchange yield (b) depending on the temperature, 70 °C (green), 50 °C (blue), 30 °C (red), and 10 °C (black), and inset show crystallinity before and after SCSC guest exchange.

elements.content: Wide range of liquid guest molecules crystallographically solved via present SCSC guest exchange system: guest molecules were classified as alicyclics, aromatics, and chains, as indicated in the figure (a) and representative crystal structures of guest molecules determined by SCSC guest exchange within ensemble channels: only trans-decahydronaphthalene adsorbed from a mixture of trans- and cis-mixture; long chains (1-dodecyne); a sticky liquid (styrene); chiral compounds ((R)-(−)-glycidyl butyrate, (S)-(+)-glycidyl butyrate, (R)-(+)-limonene, (S)-(−)-limonene) (b).
elements.clean_text: 5  Wide range of liquid guest molecules crystallographically solved via present SCSC guest exchange system: guest molecules were classified as alicyclics, aromatics, and chains, as indicated in the figure (a) and representative crystal structures of guest molecules determined by SCSC guest exchange within ensemble channels: only trans-decahydronaphthalene adsorbed from a mixture of trans- and cis-mixture; long chains (1-dodecyne); a sticky liquid (styrene); chiral compounds ((R)-(-)-glycidyl butyrate, (S)-(+)-glycidyl butyrate, (R)-(+)-limonene, (S)-(-)-limonene) (b).

elements.content: Among them, the representative structures of the guest molecules such as trans-decahydronaphthalene, styrene, 1-dodecyne, (R)-(−)-glycidyl butyrate, (S)-(+)-glycidyl butyrate, (R)-(+)-limonene, and (S)-(−)-limonene are listed in b. For all of the molecular structures, of course, the helical orientation of the 2D ensembles was preserved both before and after the SCSC guest exchange. However, the interlayer interactions (2.9–3.6 Å) and the sliding distances (1.0–2.9 Å) of the layers were dependent on the shape and size of guest molecules; thus, both the structure and the position of the guest molecules determined the channel patterns, as shown in . The channel entrance’s diameters were in the range of (2.0–4.7) × (5.0–7.3) Å2; that is, the channel behaves like a large intestine. Thus, general liquid compounds from n-propanol to n-dodecane and from cyclopentane to 1,5-cyclooctadiene, irrespective of functional groups, were smoothly exchanged into the channel instead of the original solvate molecules. The significant feature is that all of the SCSC exchanged guest molecules within the channel were successfully refined, thereby clearly displaying the structures of the various liquid chemicals irrespective of bulkiness, chain length, and functional groups. Long chains such as 1-octanol, n-decane, 1-bromodecane, and n-dodecane were smoothly exchanged into the channel and positioned therein cross-wise. Chiral molecules such as (R)-(−)-glycidyl butyrate and (S)-(+)-glycidyl butyrate were similarly inserted into the channel, and their crystal structures were satisfactorily solved. In the case of the decahydronaphthalene guest, a mixture of cis- and trans-isomer was employed in the SCSC exchange, but only the trans-isomeric chair form was adsorbed into the channel, resulting in the formation of the smooth channel shape. That is, the present porous channel clearly discriminated the isomers. 1,5-Cyclooctadiene exists as a typical tub-conformer within the channel. Thus, all of the guest molecules were safely nestled within the intestine-like channels depicted in and S7.
elements.clean_text: Among them, the representative structures of the guest molecules such as trans-decahydronaphthalene, styrene, 1-dodecyne, (R)-(-)-glycidyl butyrate, (S)-(+)-glycidyl butyrate, (R)-(+)-limonene, and (S)-(-)-limonene are listed in b. For all of the molecular structures, of course, the helical orientation of the 2D ensembles was preserved both before and after the SCSC guest exchange. However, the interlayer interactions (2.9-3.6 Å) and the sliding distances (1.0-2.9 Å) of the layers were dependent on the shape and size of guest molecules; thus, both the structure and the position of the guest molecules determined the channel patterns, as shown in . The channel entrance's diameters were in the range of (2.0-4.7) × (5.0-7.3) Å2; that is, the channel behaves like a large intestine. Thus, general liquid compounds from n-propanol to n-dodecane and from cyclopentane to 1,5-cyclooctadiene, irrespective of functional groups, were smoothly exchanged into the channel instead of the original solvate molecules. The significant feature is that all of the SCSC exchanged guest molecules within the channel were successfully refined, thereby clearly displaying the structures of the various liquid chemicals irrespective of bulkiness, chain length, and functional groups. Long chains such as 1-octanol, n-decane, 1-bromodecane, and n-dodecane were smoothly exchanged into the channel and positioned therein cross-wise. Chiral molecules such as (R)-(-)-glycidyl butyrate and (S)-(+)-glycidyl butyrate were similarly inserted into the channel, and their crystal structures were satisfactorily solved. In the case of the decahydronaphthalene guest, a mixture of cis- and trans-isomer was employed in the SCSC exchange, but only the trans-isomeric chair form was adsorbed into the channel, resulting in the formation of the smooth channel shape. That is, the present porous channel clearly discriminated the isomers. 1,5-Cyclooctadiene exists as a typical tub-conformer within the channel. Thus, all of the guest molecules were safely nestled within the intestine-like channels depicted in  and S7.

elements.content: Furthermore, 2­(THF)·2/3­(MeOH)·1/3­(H2O)@1 crystal in tetrahydrofuran were easily transformed into 3­(THF)@1. Then, 3­(Dioxane)@1 and 3­(Benzene)@1 were interconvertible within 10 h in each other’s media at 50 °C (Figure S8). Thus, all of the guest molecules can be considered to be exchangeable in each media. The relevant 1H NMR spectra of all of the SCSC exchanged guest species are listed in Figure S9. Even a small quantity of guest molecules (0.02 mL) is sufficient to obtain a guest-exchanged single crystal suitable for X-ray crystallography. The SCSC guest exchange at 30 °C for 1 day was demonstrated to be satisfactory for structure determination of guest molecules within channels. The SCSC guest exchange even at the high temperatures of 50 and 70 °C in most media preserves good crystallinity suitable for X-ray single crystallography. However, the SCSC guest exchanges of 2­(THF)·2/3­(MeOH)·1/3­(H2O)@1 in phenol, nitrobenzene, acetonitrile, benzonitrile, methanol, benzaldehyde, 1-methyl-1-cyclohexene, and 2-cyclopenten-1-one were failed because the crystals were dissolved in the liquids. Whereas the SCSC guest exchanged of 2­(THF)·2/3­(MeOH)·1/3­(H2O)@1 in dichloromethane, iodobenzene, chloroform, toluene, fluorobenzene, and acetone were accomplished, the exchanged crystals were not suitable for single crystallography because of serious cracking on the crystals. Another important factor in SCSC exchange is guest-media density. For example, because of 2­(THF)·2/3­(MeOH)·1/3­(H2O)@1 crystal was floating in high-density media such as CH2I2, CH2Br2, and iodobenzene, the SCSC guest exchange was ineffective. Although small guest molecules such as acetone and dichloromethane were smoothly inserted into the channels, the exchanged guest molecules easily came out of them. Regardless, SCSC guest exchange suitable for X-ray single crystallography was accomplished at >75% success rate. Thus, for the 1 system, the main driving forces of efficient SCSC exchange for the wide range of guest molecules can be explained in terms of the excess quantity of guest media and sponge-type flexible open-channels the 2D ensemble. The efficient SCSC guest exchangeability for a wide range of liquid samples indicates that there are no significant interactions between channels and guest molecules. Both inert silver­(I) ion and the stable helical enantiomer-paired layers seem to be partly indebted to the role of a stable platform for the structure determination of general liquid samples. The guest molecules exist safely within the open channels, which tells us that both the pyridyl and the phenyl groups as aromatic walls make the skeletal porous structure pliable for acceptance of various guest molecules. In particular, the channel is appropriate for adsorption of a wide range of liquid molecules, which indicates that the porous ensemble undergoes somewhat flexible response via the possible interlayer movement of the 2D skeleton. Thus, crystal 1 is an efficient, reproducible, and tolerant system for molecular structure determination of various liquid chemicals in an SCSC guest exchange manner. Moreover, crystal 1, with its porosity, is perfectly recyclable for several SCSC exchanges.
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, 2(THF)⋅2/3(MeOH)⋅1/3(H2O)@1 crystal in tetrahydrofuran were easily transformed into 3(THF)@1. Then, 3(Dioxane)@1 and 3(Benzene)@1 were interconvertible within 10 h in each other's media at 50 °C (Figure S8). Thus, all of the guest molecules can be considered to be exchangeable in each media. The relevant 1H NMR spectra of all of the SCSC exchanged guest species are listed in Figure S9. Even a small quantity of guest molecules (0.02 mL) is sufficient to obtain a guest-exchanged single crystal suitable for X-ray crystallography. The SCSC guest exchange at 30 °C for 1 day was demonstrated to be satisfactory for structure determination of guest molecules within channels. The SCSC guest exchange even at the high temperatures of 50 and 70 °C in most media preserves good crystallinity suitable for X-ray single crystallography. However, the SCSC guest exchanges of 2(THF)⋅2/3(MeOH)⋅1/3(H2O)@1 in phenol, nitrobenzene, acetonitrile, benzonitrile, methanol, benzaldehyde, 1-methyl-1-cyclohexene, and 2-cyclopenten-1-one were failed because the crystals were dissolved in the liquids. Whereas the SCSC guest exchanged of 2(THF)⋅2/3(MeOH)⋅1/3(H2O)@1 in dichloromethane, iodobenzene, chloroform, toluene, fluorobenzene, and acetone were accomplished, the exchanged crystals were not suitable for single crystallography because of serious cracking on the crystals. Another important factor in SCSC exchange is guest-media density. For example, because of 2(THF)⋅2/3(MeOH)⋅1/3(H2O)@1 crystal was floating in high-density media such as CH2I2, CH2Br2, and iodobenzene, the SCSC guest exchange was ineffective. Although small guest molecules such as acetone and dichloromethane were smoothly inserted into the channels, the exchanged guest molecules easily came out of them. Regardless, SCSC guest exchange suitable for X-ray single crystallography was accomplished at >75% success rate. Thus, for the 1 system, the main driving forces of efficient SCSC exchange for the wide range of guest molecules can be explained in terms of the excess quantity of guest media and sponge-type flexible open-channels the 2D ensemble. The efficient SCSC guest exchangeability for a wide range of liquid samples indicates that there are no significant interactions between channels and guest molecules. Both inert silver(I) ion and the stable helical enantiomer-paired layers seem to be partly indebted to the role of a stable platform for the structure determination of general liquid samples. The guest molecules exist safely within the open channels, which tells us that both the pyridyl and the phenyl groups as aromatic walls make the skeletal porous structure pliable for acceptance of various guest molecules. In particular, the channel is appropriate for adsorption of a wide range of liquid molecules, which indicates that the porous ensemble undergoes somewhat flexible response via the possible interlayer movement of the 2D skeleton. Thus, crystal 1 is an efficient, reproducible, and tolerant system for molecular structure determination of various liquid chemicals in an SCSC guest exchange manner. Moreover, crystal 1, with its porosity, is perfectly recyclable for several SCSC exchanges.

elements.content: For THF@2, neither the coordinate nor the simple solvate tetrahydrofuran molecules in the various media under the same conditions were exchanged. The different exchangeability between 2­(THF)·2/3­(MeOH)·1/3­(H2O)@1 and THF@2 indicates that the porous shape of the crystals is a significant factor in SCSC guest exchange. The open channels, for instance, should be essential to efficient SCSC guest exchange. Thus, the solvate tetrahydrofuran molecules of crystal THF@2 in dioxane media, even at 70 °C after 4 days, were not replaced by dioxane molecules. The crystallinity of THF@2 in benzene or dioxane media was perfectly preserved, even though no solvate exchange occurred. The reactivity of guest molecules within the confined space has been tested, and styrene molecules within the channel were found to be resistant to both light irradiation and thermal treatment.
elements.clean_text: For THF@2, neither the coordinate nor the simple solvate tetrahydrofuran molecules in the various media under the same conditions were exchanged. The different exchangeability between 2(THF)⋅2/3(MeOH)⋅1/3(H2O)@1 and THF@2 indicates that the porous shape of the crystals is a significant factor in SCSC guest exchange. The open channels, for instance, should be essential to efficient SCSC guest exchange. Thus, the solvate tetrahydrofuran molecules of crystal THF@2 in dioxane media, even at 70 °C after 4 days, were not replaced by dioxane molecules. The crystallinity of THF@2 in benzene or dioxane media was perfectly preserved, even though no solvate exchange occurred. The reactivity of guest molecules within the confined space has been tested, and styrene molecules within the channel were found to be resistant to both light irradiation and thermal treatment.

elements.content: In conclusion, this article exemplifies the functionalities demonstrating the subtlety of solvents and counteranions in the construction of the helix-enantiomeric multilayered ensemble. This flexible porous ensemble is the most efficient, reproducible, stable, and flexible SCSC exchange system for single crystal structure determination of all kinds of liquid samples via an easy SCSC guest method. These porous crystalline materials are practically able to solve the crystal structures for most liquid chemicals, to >75% success rate. Such a substantial channel for SCSC guest exchange without destruction of the skeleton is a practical matrix suitable for safe storage, discrimination, confined reaction, and crystal structure determination for all liquid chemicals except strong amine substitutes. Furthermore, this channel system shows a delicate temperature-dependent SCSC guest exchangeability. Further experiments and pervasive applications are in progress, the results of which will help to open up key future avenues even in the fields of molecular reactor, recognition, separation, and release.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, this article exemplifies the functionalities demonstrating the subtlety of solvents and counteranions in the construction of the helix-enantiomeric multilayered ensemble. This flexible porous ensemble is the most efficient, reproducible, stable, and flexible SCSC exchange system for single crystal structure determination of all kinds of liquid samples via an easy SCSC guest method. These porous crystalline materials are practically able to solve the crystal structures for most liquid chemicals, to >75% success rate. Such a substantial channel for SCSC guest exchange without destruction of the skeleton is a practical matrix suitable for safe storage, discrimination, confined reaction, and crystal structure determination for all liquid chemicals except strong amine substitutes. Furthermore, this channel system shows a delicate temperature-dependent SCSC guest exchangeability. Further experiments and pervasive applications are in progress, the results of which will help to open up key future avenues even in the fields of molecular reactor, recognition, separation, and release.

cln_elements.content:
A methanol solution (2 mL) of AgCF3SO3 (2.57 mg, 0.01 mmol) was slowly diffused into a tetrahydrofuran solution (2 mL) of L (4.83 mg, 0.01 mmol). Colorless [Ag2(CF3SO3)2L2]·2C4H8O·2/3CH3OH·1/3H2O crystals were formed at the interface and were obtained after 5 days in a 61.2% yield. mp 230 °C (dec). Anal. Calcd for C194H184Ag6F18N18O63S6: C, 47.1; H, 3.79; N, 5.07%. Found: C, 46.90; H, 3.71; N, 5.12%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 1726 (s), 1411 (s), 1328 (s), 1276 (s, CF3SO3 –), 1162 (s, CF3SO3 –), 1122 (s), 1047 (m), 1031 (s, CF3SO3 –), 755 (s), 701 (s), 647 (m).

THF@2

A tetrahydrofuran solution (2 mL) of L (4.83 mg, 0.01 mmol) was slowly diffused into an aqueous solution (2 mL) of AgPF6 (2.53 mg, 0.01 mmol). Colorless of [Ag2L2(C4H8O)2]­(PF6)2·C4H8O crystals were formed at the interface and were obtained after 5 days in a 66% yield. mp 226 °C (dec). Anal. Calcd for C66H66N6O15P2Ag2F12: C, 46.94; H, 3.94; N, 4.98%. Found: C, 47.10; H, 4.01; N, 4.82%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 1724 (s), 1268 (s), 1124 (m), 835 (s, PF6 –), 754 (s), 705 (s), 563 (m).
cln_elements.clean_text:
2(THF)⋅2/3(MeOH)⋅1/3(H2O)@1

A methanol solution (2 mL) of AgCF3SO3 (2.57 mg, 0.01 mmol) was slowly diffused into a tetrahydrofuran solution (2 mL) of L (4.83 mg, 0.01 mmol). Colorless [Ag2(CF3SO3)2L2]⋅2C4H8O⋅2/3CH3OH⋅1/3H2O crystals were formed at the interface and were obtained after 5 days in a 61.2% yield. mp 230 °C (dec). Anal. Calcd for C194H184Ag6F18N18O63S6: C, 47.1; H, 3.79; N, 5.07%. Found: C, 46.90; H, 3.71; N, 5.12%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 1726 (s), 1411 (s), 1328 (s), 1276 (s, CF3SO3 -), 1162 (s, CF3SO3 -), 1122 (s), 1047 (m), 1031 (s, CF3SO3 -), 755 (s), 701 (s), 647 (m).

THF@2

A tetrahydrofuran solution (2 mL) of L (4.83 mg, 0.01 mmol) was slowly diffused into an aqueous solution (2 mL) of AgPF6 (2.53 mg, 0.01 mmol). Colorless of [Ag2L2(C4H8O)2](PF6)2⋅C4H8O crystals were formed at the interface and were obtained after 5 days in a 66% yield. mp 226 °C (dec). Anal. Calcd for C66H66N6O15P2Ag2F12: C, 46.94; H, 3.94; N, 4.98%. Found: C, 47.10; H, 4.01; N, 4.82%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 1724 (s), 1268 (s), 1124 (m), 835 (s, PF6 -), 754 (s), 705 (s), 563 (m).

cln_elements.content: Detailed crystal structure for 2­(THF)·2/3­(MeOH)·1/3­(H2O)@1 showing geometry around Ag­(I) (a), side and top views of multilayered open-channel status (b), and ligand helicity (c).
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Detailed crystal structure for 2(THF)⋅2/3(MeOH)⋅1/3(H2O)@1 showing geometry around Ag(I) (a), side and top views of multilayered open-channel status (b), and ligand helicity (c).

cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of 2­(THF)·2/3­(MeOH)·1/3­(H2O)@1 in the (1 0 1̅) direction, showing the entrance shape of channels constructed via interlayer π–π interactions of 2D ensembles. The inset shows the hcb (63) topological skeleton of the monolayered 2D. The green color designates the inner-area of the channels. n-Dodecane@1.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Crystal structure of 2(THF)⋅2/3(MeOH)⋅1/3(H2O)@1 in the (1 0 1̅) direction, showing the entrance shape of channels constructed via interlayer π-π interactions of 2D ensembles. The inset shows the hcb (63) topological skeleton of the monolayered 2D. The green color designates the inner-area of the channels. n-Dodecane@1.

cln_elements.content: Schematic image showing interlayer stretching and sliding directions of 2D layers (a). Channel shapes based on flexible response manner depending on bulkiness and shape of guest molecules, 2­(THF)·2/3­(MeOH)·1/3­(H2O)@1 (b), 8/3­(iso-PrOH)@1 (c), trans-Decahydronaphthalene@1 (d), 3/2­(Styrene)@1 (e), and n-Dodecane@1 (f).
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Schematic image showing interlayer stretching and sliding directions of 2D layers (a). Channel shapes based on flexible response manner depending on bulkiness and shape of guest molecules, 2(THF)⋅2/3(MeOH)⋅1/3(H2O)@1 (b), 8/3(iso-PrOH)@1 (c), trans-Decahydronaphthalene@1 (d), 3/2(Styrene)@1 (e), and n-Dodecane@1 (f).

cln_elements.content: Time-dependent 1H NMR monitoring of SCSC guest exchange 2­(THF)·2/3­(MeOH)·1/3­(H2O)@1 to 3­(Dioxane)@1 at 50 °C (dagger, Me2SO-d 6; red, dioxane) (a), the SCSC guest exchange yield (b) depending on the temperature, 70 °C (green), 50 °C (blue), 30 °C (red), and 10 °C (black), and inset show crystallinity before and after SCSC guest exchange.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  Time-dependent 1H NMR monitoring of SCSC guest exchange 2(THF)⋅2/3(MeOH)⋅1/3(H2O)@1 to 3(Dioxane)@1 at 50 °C (dagger, Me2SO-d 6; red, dioxane) (a), the SCSC guest exchange yield (b) depending on the temperature, 70 °C (green), 50 °C (blue), 30 °C (red), and 10 °C (black), and inset show crystallinity before and after SCSC guest exchange.

cln_elements.content: Wide range of liquid guest molecules crystallographically solved via present SCSC guest exchange system: guest molecules were classified as alicyclics, aromatics, and chains, as indicated in the figure (a) and representative crystal structures of guest molecules determined by SCSC guest exchange within ensemble channels: only trans-decahydronaphthalene adsorbed from a mixture of trans- and cis-mixture; long chains (1-dodecyne); a sticky liquid (styrene); chiral compounds ((R)-(−)-glycidyl butyrate, (S)-(+)-glycidyl butyrate, (R)-(+)-limonene, (S)-(−)-limonene) (b).
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  Wide range of liquid guest molecules crystallographically solved via present SCSC guest exchange system: guest molecules were classified as alicyclics, aromatics, and chains, as indicated in the figure (a) and representative crystal structures of guest molecules determined by SCSC guest exchange within ensemble channels: only trans-decahydronaphthalene adsorbed from a mixture of trans- and cis-mixture; long chains (1-dodecyne); a sticky liquid (styrene); chiral compounds ((R)-(-)-glycidyl butyrate, (S)-(+)-glycidyl butyrate, (R)-(+)-limonene, (S)-(-)-limonene) (b).

metadata.title:
Practical Porous Matrix for Molecular Structure Determination
of General Liquid Chemicals
